1900.name: Van Ginkel 1997
1900.description: Until the introduction of modern dances, bodily contact between women and men who danced was restricted to a minimum and traditional social dancing demanded discipline and restraint, a legacy of court culture

1900.name: Derks 1982, 1991 Maatjens 1995
1900.description: The joy of dancing allowed young people to escape from the prying eyes of their parents, teachers, priests, pastors, and other directors, freeing them from the strict social control of everyday life.

1900.name: Rob van Ginkel
1900.description:
THE EARLY 20TH CENTURY
THE INTRODUCTION OF MODERN DANCE

;one-step, two-step, shimmy, foxtrot, Boston, Charleston, cakewalk and tango had reached the Netherlands via American troops deployed in France. 

Almost overnight, these dances became immensely popular. Dance halls catering for young dancers were quickly established, while many restaurants and cafés also provided facilities to dance. within a few years it was possible to listen to dance and entertainment music on the radio.

1914.name: Van Dorp
1914.description: Moralists were deeply worried about dancehalls. They perceived them as seats of evil, the materialization of burgeoning and fast-growing corruption and immorality

1917.name: Tucht-Unie
1917.description: Tucht-Unie;an elite nationalist society combating discipline and strengthening moral power argued that national intervention is desperately needed; If this does not happen, then moral corruption among dutch youth, who were exposed to ‘demoralization’ and would possibly degenerate or decivilize (verwilderen) will occur.

1918.name: AJC
1918.description:
The establishment of the AJC;Youth Central Workers Office by the Youth Development Committee.

From the organization’s inception, AJC ideologists, among whom Koos Vorrink, Anna Sanson-Catz, Piet Tiggers and his spouse Line Tiggers, deemed folk dancing and folk singing to be of paramount signiﬁcance for the creation of a community spirit and feelings of solidarity and to check individualism and social decay.

1919.name: National Historical Folk Festival
1919.description: National Historical Folk Festival (Vaderlandsch Historisch Volksfeest) that was celebrated in the Arnhem Open Air Museum by Dirk Jan van der Ven.

1920.name: The ﬁrst Dutch jazz bands
1920.description: The ﬁrst Dutch jazz bands were established.

1925.name: Mrs. A. Sanson-Catz and Mr. A. de Koe
1925.description: Mrs. A. Sanson-Catz and Mr. A. de Koe started to collect and describe the Dutch folk dances, much was already lost.

1926.name: An international pentecostal camp in Amsterdam
1926.description: An international pentecostal camp in Amsterdam, organized by AJC. This organization actively resisted modern mass culture. AJC people were total abstainers, they did not smoke and did not go to the cinema or dance hall.

1927.name: The Catholic cultural journal Roeping
1927.description: The modern dance dances the movement, dances the impetuosity: the impetuosity that turns into delirium, into hysteria’.

1927.name: Heerkens
1927.description: He regarded it an absolute aberration that the ‘civil’ Dutch could be enchanted by such dances, especially since they originated in ‘barbaric Negro tribes, exciting themselves to erotic madness, both sexes giving rein to brutal primordial instincts’

1927.name: Brom Struick, Gerard Brom
1927.description: Brom Struick's husband Gerard Brom even maintained that a complete change of lifestyle was necessary;

1927.name: Jop Pollmann
1927.description:
The rhythm of modern dance music causes blood flow faster, to overflow with passion and to lose all self-control. According to Jop Pollmann, these ‘unnatural’ rhythms caused mental and physical anxiety, and they were indicative of the poverty of modern culture.

Uncontrolled bodily movements unsettled him. In addition, there were the ‘devilish’ instruments (the saxophone in particular), the extended instrumental improvisations that supposedly aroused the senses, and the questionable lyrics referring to lovemaking, and it did not take much time to offend moralists. In all his prudery, he deemed words such as ‘I love you’ to be a grave moral problem.

1927.name: van der Vens
1927.description: The van der Vens organized folk dance courses.

1927.name: Henri Borel
1927.description: He thought it was a total aberration for the 'decent' Dutch people to be fascinated by these dances. Especially because these dances originated from barbaric black tribes, which cannot control their brutal primal instincts between two sexes and become excited by erotic madness.

1930.name: Folk Dance and Folk Music
1930.description: In April 1930, a Netherlands Institute for Folk Dance and Folk Music (Nederlandsch Instituut voor Volks-dans en Volksmuziek) was established by Willemien Brom-Struick, Anna Sanson-Catz, Elise van der Ven-ten Bensel.

1930.name: Government committee concerning the dance problem
1930.description: The establishment in 1930 of a ‘Government committee concerning the dance problem’ (Regeerings-commissie inzake het dansvraagstuk) followed.

1930.name: Annie Meijer
1930.description: Annie Meijer, a member of the Roman Catholic Parliament, discussed the dancing matter in the Parliament, after which in 1930 a decision was made to form the Government Committee on the dance issue.

1931.name: Rapport dansvraagstuk(the committee's opinion)
1931.description: Sexual desire and possible loss of self-control contributed to the evil of dance and led toa a loss of the code of honor and decency that is anchored in public opinion. For the morally weak, the public dancehalls can even be considered the stepping stone to prostitution(especially in the relationships between higher-class boys and lower-class girls). The demise of the fabric of organic community ties was believed to be a consequence of social differentiation and specialization, which in turn had brought about social dislocation, corruption of morals and disruption of individuals. ‘America’ was the bad example and in the Netherlands, the ‘danger of contamination’ by American ‘free-thinking’ loomed large .

1931.name: Van Dieren
1931.description: In his book ‘Infectious soul diseases before and now’, He blamed the reporter of the national newspaper who dared to write positively about Charleston and its dancers in Harlem(USA) and used words such as ‘lewd, shameless and perverse doings’ and ‘mental contamination’.

1931.name: Folk Dance and Folk Music
1931.description: Elise van der Ven-ten Bensel had to leave its Board in 1931 following a conﬂict concerning the organization’s policy.

1931.name: Prime Minister Charles Ruys de Beerenbrouck
1931.description: The Government proposed 1. improving the geography of the dancehalls and their social environment, 2. to introduce supervision, and 3. to prohibit admittance of people under the age of eighteen.

1932.name: Netherlands Central Bureau of Folk Dancing
1932.description: In 1932, Elise van der Ven-ten Bensel founded the Netherlands Central Bureau of Folk Dancing (Nederlandsch Centraal Bureau voor Volksdansen).

1940.name: World War 2
1940.description: Dancing was initially permitted, but later this was also prohibited. Where dancing was allowed, it was only allowed in "civilized" German fashion. American dancing such as "SWING" was out of the question. Everywhere you found a sign with the text:

1944.name: AJC
1944.description: In wartime, the AJC decided to abolish itself.

1945.name: AJC
1945.description: The AJC was immediately re-established in 1945 and the membership grew rapidly.

1950.name: AJC
1950.description: In the 1950s, however, the membership began to fall sharply.

1959.name: AJC
1959.description: During the last congress of the AJC on 28 February 1959, it was decided to abolish the AJC.
